The DEECo Playground Framework
A User Manual

This document contains a user manual for the DEECo Playground framework. It describes the formats of scenario and configuration XML files in detail. It also provides information on the default fields and methods of the classes, which serve as base classes for entities that can be added to a scenario.

This file contains hyperlinks to the different classes of the application. These links will work only if the javadoc documentation for this project was generated. You can generate javadoc by executing ant doc command (if you have Apache Ant installed).

Contents:

1. How to write a scenario
1.1. Structure of a scenario file
1.2. Programming objects
1.3. Programming robots
1.4. Programming wheels

1. How to write a scenario

1.1. Structure of a scenario file

A scenario has to be described in an XML file that has to have the following structure:

<simulation cycles="100" logfile="filename" sizeX="100" sizeY="100" bitmap="bitmapfile" processingTime="1">
<sensors>
<!-- list of sensors-->
</sensors>
<robots>
<!-- list of robots-->
</robots>
<ensembles>
<!-- list of ensembles-->
</ensembles>
<objects>
<!-- list of objects-->
</objects>
</simulation>

This structure is formally described in XML Schema file at src/resources/Simulation.xsd. Each section (sensors, robots, ensembles, objects) can be present (in any order) or absent depending on which entities user wants to add to simulation.

Root node simulation must have attributes cycles, logfile, and either attribute bitmap or both attributes sizeX and sizeY. Those attributes have the following meaning:
      • cycles is an integer that represents a number of cycles that have to be simulated. Simulation stops after this number of cycles (you can stop it earlier, see section 2.7)
      • logfile is a relative or absolute path to a file where simulation logs will be written. After simulation is done, you can supply this file to visualization part of the program.
      • bitmap is a relative or absolute path to an image (in JPG, PNG or BMP file format) that shows positions of obstacles on the map. If this attribute is present, attributes sizeX and sizeY are ignored and size of the map is determined by size of the image in pixels. Bitmap is interpreted in such a way that only fully black pixels (0,0,0 in RGB) are recognized as obstacles on map and all other pixels are ignored.
      • sizeX and sizeY are integers that determine width and height of the field in case when bitmap is not specified. In that case, map of the environment is empty rectangle without any physical obstacles.
      • processingTime is an integer that stands for the length of WAITING phase of simulation cycle (see section 3). This attribute is optional, default value is 1.

1.2. Programming objects

Objects in simulation are non-physical DEECo components that extend class DEECoObject. Instances of this class have the following attributes:

public Coordinates position;
public String tag;
public Double size;
public final Integer oID;

where position stands for actual coordinates of the object in the environment, size for its radius (note that by default in visualization objects have square shape, not circular, but user can change that in his configuration file, see section 4.2), and tag for a string attached to the object. All those values are set in scenario file and can be changed by the object in any of its processes or by knowledge exchange in any ensemble. Each cycle of the simulation, those values are written to the simulation logs. The last attribute, oID, is a unique identifier of the object and must not be changed in order to preserve integrity of the simulation (note, that even though this attribute is marked as final, in JDEECo it still can be changed by any process or knowledge exchange).

In scenario file, each object is represented by a following node:

<object class="com.package.ObjectClass" posX="10.0" posY="10.0" size="10.0" tag="XYZ" arg="ZYX"/>

Where:
      • class is fully qualified name of object's class. Before running the simulation all classes that will be used should be placed in src/java directory.
      • posX and posY are double values that represent initial coordinates of the object.
      • size is a double value that represents initial radius of the object.
      • tag is an initial tag of the object.
      • arg is a custom string argument that will be passed to the object during its initialization. User can define how this argument is processed by overriding processArg(String arg) method.

Attributes tag and arg are optional, all other attributes are required.

Class DEECoObject contains two methods that can be overriden:

setParameters(Double x, Double y, String tag, Double size)
processArg(String arg)

Those methods define how parameters and argument will be interpreted.

Thus, in order to add an object component to simulation, you have to:
      1. Write your own object class. It has to be a valid DEECo Component (have @Component annotation) and to extend DEECoObject class.
      2. Place this class to src/java directory.
      3. Add an object node to the list of objects in your scenario XML file.

1.3. Programming robots

Robots are "physical" DEECo components that extend class DEECoRobot. Instances of this class have the following attributes:

public final Integer rID;
public SensorySystem sensor;
public Wheels wheels;
public String tag;

Where:
      • rID is a unique identifier of the robot and must not be changed in order to preserve integrity of the simulation (note, that even though this attribute is marked as final, in JDEECo it still can be changed by any process or knowledge exchange).
      • sensor is an object that provides access to all the sensors that are present on the robot. Initially contains only collision sensor, additional sensors should be registered in robot's code (usually in constructor). Details on how to add new sensors are descrribed in section 2.5.
      • wheels is an object that represents robot's actuators. You can write your own implementation of the Wheels interface for your robots or use one of the existing implementations. Details on programming wheels are described in the next section.
      • tag is a string attached to the robot. This value can be changed by the robot in any of its processes or by knowledge exchange in any ensemble.

In scenario file, each robot is represented by a following node:

<robot class="com.package.RobotClass" posX="10.0" posY="10.0" angle="90.0" size="4.5" tag="XYZ" arg="ZYX"/>

where:
      • class is fully qualified name of the robot's class. Before running the simulation all classes that will be used should be placed in src/java directory. This attribute is required.
      • posX and posY are double values that represent initial coordinates of the robot. Those attributes are required. Note, that initial positions of robots shold not contain collisions (neither with each other nor with obstacles on the map). If you will place your robots too close to each other so that their bodies will intersect, you won't be able to start a simulation.
      • angle is a rotation angle of the robot on the map relative to the north. It has to be a double value in degrees. This attribute is required.
      • size is a double value that represents initial radius of the robot. It cannot be less then 1.0. This attribute is optional, default value is 3.0.
      • tag is an initial tag of the robot. This attribute is optional, default value is empty string.
      • arg is a custom string argument that will be passed to the robot during its initialization. User can define how this argument is processed by overriding processArg(String arg) method. This attribute is optional, default value is empty string.

Class DEECoRobot contains two methods that can be overriden:

setParameters(String tag)
processArg(String arg)

Those methods define how parameters and argument will be interpreted. In most cases, you probably will not need to override the first method, since its function is only to set a tag on the robot. However, the second method does not do anything by default, so if you want your robot to change itself based on argument that you have provided to it before initialization, you will need to override that method. For example, if you want to have different sensors on two robots of a similar type, you can pass names of those sensors to them in arg attributes of their corresponding nodes and override method processArg() to register those sensors.

As you can see, robot itself does not have any information about its own position on the map, and it can't change its position directly. All the information it receives comes either from sensors or from knowledge exchange with other components. And to move through environment, robot has to use its Wheels to send actions. You can extend both of those parts yourself: by writing your own implementation of Wheels interface and by adding your own sensors. By default, a robot has only a single sensor that receives information about collisions with other objects, but if you need a robot to know its position, you can add a sensor that receives it, see CoordinatesProcessor.

Thus, in order to add a robot component to the scenario, you have to:
      1. Write your own robot class. It has to be a valid DEECo Component (have @Component annotation) and to extend DEECoRobot class.
      2. You may need to write your own implementation of the Wheels interface (see next section). Or you can use e.g. SimpleWheels class.
      3. Place the robot class into src/java directory.
      4. Add a robot node to the list of robots in your scenario XML file.


1.4. Programming wheels

Wheels is an interface with two methods:

Action sendCurrentAction(int cycle);
void setAction(double speed, double angle);

First method is called by the environment in each cycle of the simulation on each robot to get an Action object from that robot. This object represents an actual action that this robot wants to perform in this cycle. Basic action consists of two parameters: speed and rotation angle. Speed can have values from 0.0 to 1.0, it represents a distance this robot will move in this cycle (in the same units as sizes of robots and size of the field) if it will not hit an obstacle. Rotation angle represents an angle this robot will rotate in this cycle before moving (in radians). Based on presence or absence of one or both of these parameters, Action can have the following types: STAY, MOVE, ROTATE, ROTATE_AND_MOVE. This type is determined automatically in Action's constructor.
You can implement wheels in such a way that they send not an Action object, but an instance of its subclass, carrying additional information. That additional information can then be used by your SensoryInputProcessor. This way, by extending Action class you can add additional actuators to your robot that will have an effect on the environment. You can find an example of this in Firefighters example scenario.

Method setAction() can be used to set speed and rotation angle of robot in this cycle. Those two values represent a desired action, and can be supplied directly to Action's constructor. This method exists only for convenience, you can choose to set action in some other way. Unlike sendCurrentAction(), this method is not used by application, only by your own code.

1.5. Programming sensors

Sensors have two parts: actual sensor on the robot, that receives data of a specific type in each cycle, and sensory input processor (SIP) that computes those inputs for each robot and sends them.

By default, robot has only a single sensor, which collects information about collisions with other physical bodies (collision sensor). To add your own sensors you have to do the following:

1. Write your own subclass of SensoryInputProcessor<T>. Generic parameter T is a type of input that this SIP sends to robots. In that class you have to write your own implementation of the following method:

ArrayList<T> sendInputs(ArrayList<RobotPlacement> robots, ArrayList<ObjectPlacement> objects);

In this method, SIP receives a list of robots and a list of objects that are present in simulation. You can access their parameters through methods defined on RobotPlacement and ObjectPlacement classes. You can also access a map of the environment through environmentMap field and methods defined on EnvironmentMap class. Class RobotPlacement contains a reference to Action object that represents an action that this robot performes in this cycle. If you use your own extension of Action class, you can cast this object to your class here to access its additional fields (you can see an example of this in the Firefighters scenario).
From this information, you can compute inputs for each robot and return a list of those inputs. Note, that size of this list must be equal to the size of robots list, and an input on i-th position in return list will be sent to i-th robot in robots list.

2. Add the following node to the list of sensors of your scenario:

<sensor name="yoursensorname" processor="com.package.YourSensorName" arg="XYZ" />

Where:
      • processor is fully qualified name of your sensor's class. Before running the simulation this class should be placed in src/java directory.
      • name is a string that represents this sensor. This string should be unique for each sensor. The default collision sensor has name "collisions" so you cannot add a sensor with that name.
      • arg is a custom string argument that will be passed to your SIP during its initialization. You can define how this argument is processed by overriding processArg(String arg) method.

3. Register this sensor on each robot that has to carry it using following command:

sensor.registerSensor("yoursensorname", YourInputType.class);

The first argument of this call is a name that you have chosen for your sensor, the second one is a type of input that your SIP sends (its generic parameter T). The best practice is to register each sensor on each robot in robot's constructor or in the processArg initialization method . This way, each type of robot in simulation will have those sensors that you will define for them. Robots can access their sensors through method getInputFromSensor() on SensorySystem:

YourInputType input = sensor.getInputFromSensor("yoursensorname", YourInputType.class);

1.6. Programming Ensembles

To add a DEECo ensemsble to the simulation you have to place its class to src/java directory and add the following node to the list of ensembles:

<ensemble class="com.package.YourEnsemble"/>

There are no any special requirements for ensembles, any robots and objects can be connected through them.

1.7. Other features

Coordinator has two special attributes that you can use in your ensembles:

public Boolean endSignal;
public String status;

The first attribute is a signal that means that simulation should stop. After you will set it to true, simulation will stop in the next cycle. The second attribute is a status string. It is written to simulation logs every cycle and is visualised at top center of the screen afterwards. You can use it however you want. For example, in Competition Demo, it is used to display current cycle and score.

Also, Coordinator contains another attribute, that you can use only as @In parameter in your knowledge exchange. It must not be changed.

public Integer cycle = 0;

This parameter shows the number of current cycle. All the other attributes of Coordinator should not be changed.

JDEECo implementation does not enable any incapsulation, so all fields of Coordinator component can participate in any knowledge exchange. However, in order for simulation to stay consistent, you should not use any of those fields except for the ones described above.


2. How to create a visualization configuration

2.1. Standard configuration

Visualization program receives simulation logs file as its parameter, and visualizes it on the screen. After the start of the visualization, a window appears on the screen where each cycle of simulation is being visualized consecutively.

Visualization consists of separate layers that are rendered sequentially. In standard configuration, there are 3 visualization layers: object layer, robot layer and map layer. Robot layer is rendered first, it draws each robot as a red circle. Map layer draws obstacles on map, by default they are black. Object layer is rendered last, it draws objects as yellow squares.

The visualization process can be controlled with keyboard. The following commands are supported:
      • Pause/resume (space bar).
      • Rewind/fast forward (left/right arrow keys).
      • Increase/decrease the speed of visualization (up/down arrow keys).
      • Restart visualization from the beginning (enter key).

2.2. Modifying configuration

You can change default configuration by writing your own configuration XML file. This file should be valid against XML Schema at src\resources\Visualization.xsd. Cofiguration file describes visualization layers that have to be visualized on the screen. The basic structure of configuration file is the following:

<visualization zoom="5" maxCPS="10" fontColor="Green" rewindSpeed="10">
<!-- list of layers-->
</visualization>

Where:
      • zoom is a positive integer that defines the size of the visualization window. Default value is 5, so if you are visualizing a scenario with a bitmap of 100*100 pixels, its size on the screen will be 500*500 pixels.
      • maxCPS is a positive integer that defines how many cycles of the simulation will be visualized per second. Note, that this is a maximum number, and if it will be too high, actual visualization will be slower due to hardware limitations. Default value is 15.
      • fontColor is a color in which status string will be displayed. Default is black.
      • rewindSpeed is the speed of the rewind/fast forward function. Default value is 10.

Colors in configuration file can be specified in two ways. First way is by a keyword; there are 12 colors you can specify in this way, their keywords are: transparent, white, gray, black, red, green, blue, yellow, cyan, magenta, orange, brown. Keywords are case-insensitive. The other way is using RGB or RGBA format. In this format you represent color as a list of 3 (for RGB) or 4 (for RGBA) float values, separated by commas. So, any attribute that represents a color has to be either keyword or a list of 3-4 float values.

List of layers contains a single element for each visualization layer, and those layers will be rendered in the same order as they are written in the list. Remember, that 3 layers are present in the visualization by default, and if you won't write them explicitly in your list, they will be added to the end of it (in default order, with default settings).

There are 5 types of visualization layers that can be present in configuration file. Three of them were already mentioned in the section above, those are robot layer, object layer and map layer. Your configuration file cannot contain any of those layers more then once (and if you will omit any of those layers, it will still be visualized as described above). Other two types are background layers and additional layers; you can add as many of those layers to visualization as you want.

Map layer is represented with one of the following nodes:

<map texture="path/texture.png"/>
<map color="black"/>

Where color attribute has a color type described above, and texture attribute is a relative or absolute path to an image file. Note that only one of those attributes can be present.

Robot layer is represented with one of the following nodes:

<robots displayNumbers="false" displayTags="true" enableRotation="false" fontColor="Blue">
<class-based>
<default texture="path/texture.png"/>
<class name="package.Class1" texture="path/robot.png"/>
<class name="package.Class2" color="1,0.5,1"/>
</class-based>
</robots>

<robots displayNumbers="false" displayTags="true" enableRotation="false" fontColor="Blue">
<tag-based>
<default texture="path\robot.png"/>
<tag name="tag1" texture="path\robot2.png"/>
<tag name="tag2" color="white"/>
</tag-based>
</robots>

<robots displayNumbers="false" displayTags="true" enableRotation="false" fontColor="Blue">
<number-based>
<default color="Green"/>
<number number="0" texture="path\robot.png"/>
<number number="2" color="blue"/>
</number-based>
</robots>

Where:
      • displayNumbers - displays a robot's number on each robot if true. Optional, default value is false. If displayTags is true, this attribute is ignored.
      • displayTags - displays a current robot's tag on each robot if true. Optional, default value is false.
      • enablbeRotation - if true, then robots' textures will be rotating according to robots' current directions. Optional, default value is false.
      • fontColor - Color in which robots' numbers or tags will be written. Optional, default value is black.

If you won't add anything inside a robots element, then all robots will be visualized with default settings (red color). However, if you want to change settings, you have three options: class-based, tag-based and number-based visualization. In each of those options you can specify default coloring (color or texture), that will apply to all robots whose class/tag/number is not included (this element is optional). Ater default element follows a list of class/tag/number elements. Each element of this list has to contain a fully qualified name of robot's class for class-based option, a tag for tag-based option, and a number for number-based option. Also, each of those elements has to contain either color or texture attribute (with the same meaning as in map node). When robots are visualized, program first tries to find a specific coloring for its class/tag/number (depending on chosen option), and if it is not present, then robot is visualized with default coloring.

Since robots have circular shapes, their textures are automatically rounded.

Rules for defining object layer are almost the same as for robot layer, with only 3 differences:
      • Main element is named objects instead of robots
      • Attribute enableRotation is ignored (since objects have no direction)
      • There is an additional attribute circularShape. It has a boolean value, and if it is set to true, then objects will be displayed as circles, instead of squares, and their textures will be rounded (in the same way as for robots).

By default, objects are represented as yellow squares.

Background layer is represented with one of the following nodes:

<background texture="path/texture.png"/>
<background color="white"/>

In the first case, this layer will display a specified texture. It will be stretched to the size of the displayed field. In the second case, all displayed field will be filled with chosen color. You can have as much background layer as you want, though this may be useful only in case of partially-transparent textures.

2.3. Additional layers

In addition to 4 types of layers described above, you can write your own visualization layers. This option allows you to add any shapes, textures, labels or even animation to the visualization. You can find an example of using this feature in Firefighters Demo.

Each visualization layer has to extend abstract class VisualizationLayer. There is a one metod in this class that you have to define:

protected abstract void render(int cycle);

This method is called in the visualization loop, it has to draw all the elements that belong to this layer. It receives a single parameter that stands for a number of a cycle that is being visualized at the moment. To draw different elements, each VisualizationLayer contains following fields and methods:

protected ShapeRenderer shapeRenderer;
protected SpriteBatch spriteBatch;
protected BitmapFont font;

protected void drawText(String text, float centerX, float centerY);
protected final Sprite loadTexture(String path)

ShapeRenderer allows you to draw shapes on screen, SpriteBatch allows to draw textures. You can learn how to use them in libGDX tutorials.

Method drawText() allows you to display any string on the screen. The center of this string will be placed at (centerX, centerY)-coordinate (in pixels). If you want to change color and size of displayed text, use methods font.setColor(Color color) and font.getData().setScale(float scale) before calling drawText().

If you want to add your own visualization layer to the visualization, you have to specify this in your configuration file. You can add as many additional layers as you want. Additional layer is represented by a following node:

<additional class="cz.cuni.mff.d3s.deeco.playground.examples.firefighters.environment.TemperatureLayer" arg="simulation-logs/firemap.bin"/>

Where:
      • class is a fully qualified name of layer's class. Before running the visualization all classes that will be used should be placed in src/java directory. This attribute is required.
      • arg is a string argument that will be passed to this layer during its initialization. You can define how this argument is interpreted by overriding processArg() method. This attribute is optional.
